results.address: St. Paul, Minnesota
results.raw: Water Restrictions Now in Effect in Saint Paul Region at St. Paul, Minnesota
results.rawLocation: St. Paul, Minnesota
results.title: Water Restrictions Now in Effect in Saint Paul Region

-MhKfgaDusAq8uEWieEi.text: Saint Paul Regional Water Services (SPRWS) announced watering restrictions beginning Tuesday, August 17 due to drought.

nib.text:
Due to drought, Saint Paul Regional Water Services (SPRWS) announced watering restrictions beginning Tuesday, August 17.

Restrictions include:
* SPRWS customers with odd-numbered addresses can water their property only on odd-numbered days of the month.
* SPRWS customers with even-numbered addresses can water their property only on even-numbered days of the month.
* Outdoor watering is only allowed before noon or after 6 p.m. Outdoor watering is not allowed 12 p.m. to 6 p.m. (There are exceptions for nurseries, community gardens, new sod or seed, and trees watered using dripping hose, bucket, or watering bag.)

The restrictions will be enforced starting Friday, August 20th. Penalties include:
* Educational notice for first violation
* Written warning for second violation
* $50 fine for third violation
* $100 fine for fourth violation
* $150 fine and water shut off for fifth violation and beyond. There is an additional $50 fee when water is shut off.

See more details in the SPRWS announcement [here](https://www.stpaul.gov/news/saint-paul-regional-water-services-announces-watering-restrictions-amid-ongoing-drought).

Residents should also adjust sprinklers, mulch trees and plants, and take other steps to preserve water. Learn more about water conservation [here](https://www.stpaul.gov/departments/saint-paul-regional-water-services/customer-resources/water-conservation). See a water conservation flyer [here](https://www.stpaul.gov/sites/default/files/Media%20Root/Water%20Services/waterConservation.pdf). See more information from SPRWS [here](https://www.stpaul.gov/departments/saint-paul-regional-water-services).

SPRWS customers are in Saint Paul, Arden Hills, Falcon Heights, Lauderdale, Lilydale, Little Canada, Maplewood, Mendota, Mendota Heights, Roseville, and West Saint Paul.

The Minnesota Department of Natural Resources designated the restrictive phase after the Mississippi River near Anoka dropped below 1,500 cubic feet per second for five consecutive days. The local area needs 5 to 8 of rain over a month to relieve these conditions. As of August 10, 78% of the state was in severe drought, 42% was in extreme drought, and 7% was in exceptional drought.
